entry.title: Re: Crystal Reports: ToWords with UFL to change language
entry.content:
Yes, a UFL can indeed handle this use case. But the devil is in the detail:
- integers or decimals?
- need to handle number gender?
- number or currency?
- output format options?

If Crystal ToWords() works well enough for  your use case, you could use a UFL that can translate the output in the default language to the desired language. There are 3rd-party UFLs that provide such a function.

A third option, if the machine has the target language installed, is to direct the Crystal runtime to switch to the other locale.

entry.title: BYD: Internal Sales Note copied to Journal Entry Header
entry.content:
Dear SAP,

if we maintain an "Internal Sales" on the customer account on the tab "Notes" it gets written to the sales order as an "Internal Comment", then to the customer invoice and to the journal entry header and line item text as well.
How can we configure this system behavior? We do not want to have the internal sales note from the customer account on the journal entry text.

Thanks.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: BYD: Internal Sales Note copied to Journal Entry Header
entry.content:
Dear requester,

When in the customer invoice, the Internal Comments in header is the only maintained note field, it will be taken into the JE.

When the Internal Comments and Customer Info notes are maintained in the same time, Internal Comments has higher priority and will be taken into the JE.

When the user firstly maintained the internal comment and clicked SAVE. Then added customer information and clicked SAVE. these 2 notes were saved in 2 different changes. In this case, the 2nd added note which is Customer Info in this case will be taken into the JE.

it is the designed behavior. There is no configuration activity or rules to change this logic so far in the system.

Thanks,

Adie

entry.title: How to make MRP Strategy 10 ignore special procurement requirements from other plant
entry.content:
Dear expert,

I encountered an issue in a Public Cloud case and would like to seek advice from the experts here.
The customerâ€™s business model is that the demand plant issues purchase orders to the supplying plant. Independent requirements are created directly in the supplying plant. The customer wants the production plan to follow the independent requirements only, so they intend to use MRP Strategy 10.

However, we discovered an issue : even if the supplying plant uses MRP type 10, even though the supplying plant uses MRP Strategy 10, once the demand plant issues an inter-plant purchase order, the purchase requirements are still transferred to the supplying plant. As a result, during MRP calculation, the supplying plant generates additional production quantities based on those purchase order requirements.

For example, if the supplying plant independently plans to produce 500 EA and the receiving plant creates an inter-plant purchase requisition for 100 PCS, after the MRP run, the supplying plant will generate planned orders for 600 PCS, resulting in an extra 100 PCS being produced.

I tried adjusting the Mixed MRP setting and the Consumption Indicator, but neither seems to resolve the issue.

 

 

Best regards,

Lance

entry.title: Re: Migration to S/$ Hana
entry.content:
Hello @piyush_kr ,

 

AspectDetails
PossibilityYes â€” you can introduce a new currency type during or after SAP S/4HANA migration. The approach depends on whether itâ€™s a Brownfield (system conversion) or Greenfield (new implementation) project.
Common Currency Types10 â€“ Company Code Currency (Local) 20 â€“ Controlling Area Currency 30 â€“ Group Currency 40+ â€“ Custom / Freely Defined Currency Types
Migration Approach: Greenfield (New Implementation)- New system setup allows defining all currency types freely. - No restriction since historical data is not migrated. - Define currencies in configuration (OB22, FINSC_LEDGER, FINSC_FISCYEAR).
Migration Approach: Brownfield (System Conversion)- Possible to add new currencies (e.g., Group Currency) using SAPâ€™s currency conversion process. - Requires data conversion and recalculation of historical data. - Executed via SAP guided tools such as FINS_CURRENCY.
Tool / TransactionFINS_CURRENCY â€“ SAPâ€™s Currency Conversion tool for adding new currency types post-migration.
Key SAP Notes2344014 â€“ Currency Conversion in SAP S/4HANA 2549494 â€“ Adding Additional Currency in Universal Journal after Migration
Impact Areas- General Ledger (ACDOCA) - Asset Accounting - CO-PA (Profitability Analysis) - Material Ledger - Group Reporting
Configuration Adjustments- Ledger setup â€“ FINSC_LEDGER - Currency settings â€“ OB22 - Currency translation â€“ OB08, OBBS
Best Practice- Introduce new currency before migration if possible. - If added post-migration, first test in a sandbox or quality system. - Validate balances, ledgers, and reports after conversion.
Risks / Cautions- Impacts historical ledgers and financial reports. - Requires system backup and reconciliation across ACDOCA, Asset Accounting, CO, and Material Ledger.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Sucessfully automated updating Confirmation Tab of ME22N but stops on 9th row
entry.content:
Hi

I made a macro that: 


After  downloading Me5A excel file and pasting it at the macro file, you can edit Delivery dates at downloaded Excel.
After  updating, it copies the delivery dates from excel to Confirmation Tab>Field named EEIND
Since one material number appears at one time, after updating the first material number, it switches over to the 2nd material then updates that, switch to 3rd material updates that and so on.

And the macro works until..it reaches the 9th material.


After it updates the 9th material number, it attempts to switch to the 10th, fails to do so, "updates" EEIND using 10th material data [9th EEIND gets overwritten], attempts again for the 11th material but 9th material is still visible, overwrites the data and so on (á—’á—£á—•)

Here is the function that presses the drop down boxes and dynamically chooses what material number using cmbDYN_6000-LIST (The drop down box under "Item Details").

Macro 1 below

======================================
This Function basically just sets up choosing material number at the  dropdown box by giving it  3 spaces and assigning what are reserving thoses spaces as what row are we know (comboIndex). So basically it just prepares this: 

session.findById("wnd[0]/usr/subSUB0:SAPLMEGUI:0019/.............../cmbDYN_6000-LIST").key = "<space, space, space> " and spaces will be replaced later.

Example:  we are updating uisng excel's row 3 now, next row is row number 4. After you are done updating SAP using data at excel's row 3, you will now move on to material  4.

So you put "  4" replacing the 3 spaces
session.findById("wnd[0]/usr/subSUB0:SAPLMEGUI:0019/.............../cmbDYN_6000-LIST").key = "  4"
Row 4 is the result of comboIndex

=========================================
Start Macro 1



Function PressDynamicAutotext(sess As Object, ws As Worksheet, excelRow As Long, comboIndex As Long) As Boolean
Dim ctrl As Object
On Error Resume Next

Set ctrl = sess.findById("wnd[0]/usr/subSUB0:SAPLMEGUI:0019/subSUB3:SAPLMEVIEWS:1100/" & _
"subSUB2:SAPLMEVIEWS:1200/subSUB1:SAPLMEGUI:1301/subSUB1:SAPLMEGUI:6000/cmbDYN_6000-LIST")
If ctrl Is Nothing Then ws.Cells(excelRow, ERR_COL).Value = "Dynamic combo not found": PressDynamicAutotext = False: Exit Function


ctrl.SetFocus
ctrl.Key = " " & comboIndex
ctrl.SetFocus
ctrl.Key = " " & comboIndex
application.Wait Now + (0.35 / 86400#) '------------------------- I added wait time. I only have 8GB ram. I'm sorry for being poor.
PressDynamicAutotext = True

----------------------------------------------

This is troubleshooting line. I want to see if the button is successfully pressed so I put it at excel. That is why I know it did the "press" attempt. I will delete this line if everything works well

----------------------------------------------
ws.Cells(excelRow, LOG_COL).Value = ws.Cells(excelRow, LOG_COL).Value & " | Dynamic Autotext " & comboIndex & " pressed"
On Error GoTo 0
End Function

Snippet of Macro 2 below 
===============
What this does is anayze ComboIndex. Combo index is based on a counter scrollCounter = scrollCounter + 1.  It is +1 since we do not need to choose material number since it is already displayed once PO is displayed. 

First 2 lines are  just my log  in excel. 
=================
Start of part of Macro 2
...... 


If Not PressDynamicAutotext(sess, ws, i, scrollCounter) Then ws.Cells(i, ERR_COL).Value = "Dynamic Autotext failed"
If Not WaitForStatusBarClearSafe(sess) Then ws.Cells(i, ERR_COL).Value = "Status bar didn't clear after dynamic autotext"
application.Wait Now + (0.35 / 86400#)
scrollCounter = scrollCounter + 1 ' increment for next table row

NextRow:
application.Wait Now + (0.1 / 86400#)
Set targetTable = Nothing: Set targetAB = Nothing: Set targetEEIND = Nothing: Set cmb = Nothing: Set UserArea = Nothing
Next i

========================================
Again it worked for the first 9 material number but failed on 10th onwards.

I tried adding a pause after 9th row [and pauses again on the 18th] , pop up a dialog box to tell user choose material 10 manually, press ok to continue macro. But it it know got stuck on the 10th material ðŸ˜ž

Thanks

entry.title: Re: Demand forecasting for festivals
entry.content:
Hi Prabhat
Please follow the steps below:
1. Create a key figure indicating the festive period like month/weeks of Diwali by a binary value in past and future.

2. In the 'Manage Forecast Models' app, select models such as Multiple Linear Regression or Gradient Boosting.

3. Add your event variables (the indicators you created) as independent variables (exogenous regressors)

As a result in next forecast run system will learn the sales (or demand) uplift or pattern associated with unique event codes or indicators, even though the holidays shift from year to year. In future forecasts will be generated based on the  the event indicator. In your case for forecast periods where Diwali will occur.

I would recommend to use Gradient Boosting for its capability to handle categorical inputs representing events, which is superior for non-linear holiday effects.

Hope this helps.

-Rahul Mohnot

entry.title: Re: How to enter Attribute on aggregated level to get it...
entry.content:
Hi BR, Halyna,

There are two ways to accomplish what you want, 

Option1:  Through "Manage Rules for Master Data" app-

Step1: You create an attribute for example "LOCPRODDESIREDATTR" in LOCATIONPRODUCT master data

Step2: Create a Rule for LOCATIONPRODUCT master data with Filter condition on LOCATION master attribute "DESIREDATTR" >=0 

Step3: Create join condition between Location and LocationProduct master data.

Step4: LOCPRODDESIREDATTR = DESIREDATTR

if you are new to this please use link : https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_INTEGRATED_BUSINESS_PLANNING/feae3cea3cc549aaa9d9de7d363a83e6/ee1f6ace105b4a8e9a527b9b2bb9b778.html?q=maintain+Master+Data+Rule

Option2:  Through Attribute as Key figure and using indirect input at LOCPROD level to extend the Location level value to LocationProduct level

Step1 : Create attribute as key figure for DESIREDATTR@WKLOC level

Step2: Create additional calculation in same Key Figure DESIREDATTR@WKLOCPROD using indirect input as any key figure Like: IndependentDemand, DependentDemand which is at the same planning level and you are sure that it will have planning object generated during the planning process.

You can use this additional calculation in another Key figure with same planning level with equal operator or in calculation wherever you want.

 

Hope this helps,

-Rahul Mohnot

entry.title: Email triggers - removal of registration in Pending status
entry.content:
When removing one participant from a class who is sitting in the pending status (awaiting chief approval), it triggers the Learning event cancellation email to be sent to the user, manager and facilitator (including the calendar invite removing the item from the facilitators calendar). 

If I follow the same steps and remove someone who is actively enrolled in the class, it triggers the class withdrawal emails. 

I need to understand the logic behind this? I've been told it is expected system behaviour but why would I want to trigger an email that the class has been cancelled when removing one attendee. 

The process I'm following to remove people from the class is: Opening the class in SF, clicking the three dots next to the name in the registration tab and selecting remove.

entry.title: Opportunity to Shape the Future of Compatible Unit Management!
entry.content:
SAP's Customer Engagement Initiatives (CEI) platform, found at https://influence.sap.com, empowers SAP customers and partners by offering early access to SAP product developments. As a participant, you have the opportunity to interact directly with SAP product experts to influence future product direction.

As a part of CEI, we are launching a strategic initiative to transform and standardize Compatible Unit (CU) management across industries. This is a unique chance to collaborate on reimagining how CUs are defined, managed, and executedâ€”making them more agile, scalable, and aligned with evolving customer needs.

  • Standardize CU practices to ensure consistency and interoperability across industries.
  • Align CU processes with customer-specific scenarios, enhancing relevance and usability.
  • Explore short-term and long-term solutions including:
    • CU integration into maintenance orders

  • Streamlined creation of maintenance orders

entry.title: Re: Difference in SAP Integration Suite for SAP SuccessFa...
entry.content:
The main distinction between SAP Integration Suite for SuccessFactors and SAP Integration Suite â€“ Standard Edition lies in their licensing scope and feature entitlements, particularly in how integration between SuccessFactors and other systems is packaged and priced.

Key Differences & Customer Benefits

Aspect Integration Suite for SuccessFactors Integration Suite â€“ Standard Edition
Target Use CaseTailored for organizations that primarily need to integrate SuccessFactors with other SAP or non-SAP systemsGeneral-purpose integration across cloud, on-prem, and hybrid landscapes
Cost & LicensingUsually offered at a lower entry cost when your primary integration use case is SuccessFactors-centricBroader license covering more capabilities; more expensive but more flexible
Feature CoverageMay include pre-built integration content / connectors specific to SuccessFactorsFull access to Integration Suiteâ€™s capabilities: Cloud Integration, API Management, Open Connectors, etc. SAP Community+2SAP+2
Scalability & FlexibilityGood for a constrained integration landscape focused on HR data flowsIdeal when your integration needs expand across business units, applications, and domains
Upgrade PathYou may need to upgrade or augment to access full suite featuresAlready includes the full feature set and can scale with your needs SAP Community+1

From a customer perspective, if your integration footprint is limited to SuccessFactors and a few connected systems, the specialized package might give you cost advantages while satisfying your use case. But if you foresee needing broader integrations across ERP, CRM, third-party cloud apps, or extension services, the Standard Edition gives you more flexibility without needing add-ons later.

In my SAP certification preparations, Iâ€™ve seen scenarios where clients started with a narrow license and later faced additional costs to â€œunlockâ€ full integration features. Using materials from Pass4Future helped me understand how to map business integration needs to the correct SAP licensing choice, aligning architectural decisions with license boundaries.

For official reference, you can review:

  • SAPâ€™s Integration Suite product page: â€œSAP Integration Suiteâ€ SAP 

  • SAPâ€™s pricing and editions documentation: â€œSAP Integration Suite Pricingâ€ SAP+1 

Let me know if you want help modeling your expected integration use cases so you pick the right license from the start.

entry.title: Stock on Posting Date Report Showing Inconsistent Values in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
entry.content:
We are experiencing a critical data consistency issue with the Stock on Posting Date report. The report shows different closing stock values when executed simultaneously across multiple user sessions, despite no manual entries being passed by the team.

Observations

Scenario 1: Sequential Retrievals (Same Login)

 

First retrieval: 1,433,243,957 units

Second retrieval: 1,433,223,314 units

Difference: 20,643 units

Time interval: 2 minutes

No manual entries were posted between retrievals

 

Scenario 2: Simultaneous Multi-Session Execution

 

Ran the same report simultaneously on 3-4 different (or same) user logins

Each session returned different stock values from the same report

No parameter variations were made

 

Questions & Concerns

 

Why does the same report show different values when run simultaneously across different sessions? This suggests either a data consistency issue or query execution problem rather than timing-related variance.

What could cause a 20,643 unit variance within a 2-minute interval when no manual transactions have been posted?

Is this expected behavior in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, or does this indicate:

 

Database lock contention or transaction isolation issues?

Uncommitted transactions being read differently by different sessions?

Cache synchronization problems?

Authorization/User Exit filtering differences?

 

 

 

Investigation Performed

 

Confirmed no manual journal entries or goods movements were posted by the team during the test period

Verified that all report executions used identical parameters and variant settings

Confirmed the issue occurs consistently across multiple simultaneous sessions

#SAP-S4HANA-Cloud #Inventory #Stock-Management #Data-Consistency #Reporting

entry.title: Re: 1,500Ã— Faster: ABAP Cloud API with â€œJustâ€ Gzip
entry.content:
@natanael1 

  1. OData medium is JSON (or Atom XML which is deprecated since V4.0). How else than Base64 can you send compressed data via OData? I mean, what's better?
  2. It was just a guess, please forget it: I read too late that the magic would be with Transfer-Encoding, not with Content-Encoding, but if I believe rfc2616 - Content-Encoding vs Transfer Encoding in HTTP - Stack Overflow, "Transfer Encodings other than "chunked" (sadly) aren't implemented in practice". If I understand well, the header field "Transfer-Encoding: chunked" is implemented by the HTTP server or client, not by the receiving application, while Content-Encoding (like Content-Type and the rest of the message) is an information to be used or not by each client or server, and so it could be absent if the payload is always gzipped and the receiving application knows that and does the ungzip systematically.

entry.title: Field Level Infotype Update with Business Integration Builder
entry.content:
Business Context

SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) serves as the system of record for core HR data, including the attributes necessary to manage an employeeâ€™s lifecycle processes, such as hiring, changes in job and personal information, and more. In contrast, the payroll system is responsible for managing compliance-related data, including tax details, social insurance information, garnishments, and other statutory or regulatory requirements.

Employee data maintained in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central is replicated to the relevant Infotypes in SAP ERP HCM or SAP S/4 HANA. A single Infotype could have some fields being replicated form Employee central and a few payroll relevant fields that are not captured in Employee Central. Previously if such payroll relevant data was manually entered in SAP ERP HCM or SAP S/4 HANA for fields belonging to an Infotype which is replicated from Employee Central, then manual entries was overwritten the next time data was replicated from Employee Central. As a result, customers often had to exclude such Infotypes from their replication scope and maintain them completely in the backend Payroll system either by using SAP GUI transactions or UI mashups. With this approach customers were unable to use the full flexibility of Employee Central as the modern cloud based HR system.

Field Level Infotype Update : Solution Overview

 Employee master data replication from Employee Central using Business Integration Builder (BIB) now supports Field-Level Infotype Updates, enabling the partial replication of Infotype data from Employee Central without overwriting payroll-relevant Infotype fields maintained in SAP ERP HCM or SAP S/4 HANA.

Due to this newly introduced flexibility in master data replication, the data cut can now be configured at Infotype field level. You can now use Employee Central to maintain data of the available fields while entering the missing payroll-relevant fields of that infotype in SAP ERP HCM or SAP S/4HANA, either by using SAP GUI transactions or infotype UI mashups. The replication preserves existing payroll-related data, merges it with the incoming data from Employee Central, and updates the infotype with the combined details. This ensures you can use full capabilities of Employee Central as your cloud-based HR system and bring additional Infotypes in your replication scope.

Solution Status and Scope for 2H 2025

This feature of partial replication with field level Infotype update generally available with 2H 2025 release in :-

  • Support Package 40 of SFSF EC INTEGRATION (PA_SE_IN) add-on
  • Support Package 06 of SFSF EC S4 HCM INTEGRATION (ECS4HCM) add-on

For more details, refer to the What's New Viewer, ECS4HCM Help Guide, PA_SE_IN Help Guide.

The payroll relevant fields can now be protected during replication for the following Infotypes and their corresponding secondary Infotypes :-

  • Infotype 0001 (Organizational Assignment)
  • Infotype 0016 (Contract Elements)

This feature is intended for customers running payroll in SAP ERP HCM or SAP S/4HANA who are either beginning their Employee Central implementation or have already implemented it and want to broaden its usage scope.

To preserve historical Infotype data maintained in SAP ERP HCM or SAP S/4 HANA, it is recommended to use Field Level Infotype Update in combination with Infotype Specific Full Transmission Start Date functionality that is also introduced in 2H 2025.

Configuration Requirements

  • Set the constant value of EC to ERP: Don't overwrite Payroll related Infotype fields option in view  V_ECPAO_CONSTANTS to X.
  • Define the payroll-relevant fields of Infotype 0001 (Org Assignment) and Infotype 0016 (Contract Elements) that should be protected during employee master data replication from Employee Central, using the view ECPAO_INFTY_FLD available under Customizing for Business Integration Builder.

The below screenshots illustrates how to configure this :-

 

Subtypes and Country Grouping fields are optional. If a particular field is relevant for all countries, then this should be empty.

Fields belonging to Custom Includes can be configured in this customizing for Field Level Infotype Update and protected during replication.

If an Infotype field is already mapped in the Transformation Template Group used for employee data replication, it should not be included in the Field-Level Infotype Update configuration. Doing so will cause replication errors due to data conflicts.

Additionally, it is recommended to exclude Infotype fields that are derived by the HCM Framework.

Use Case Example

Letâ€™s take an example with Infotype 0016 (Contract Elements)

The following configuration ensures that fields KGZFR (Sick Pay Supplement Period Number) and KGZZH (Sick Pay Supplement Period Unit) are protected during replication for employees belonging to Germany :-

Consider the following scenario involving sequential actions in Employee Central and SAP S4 HANA system:

  1. Hire an employee in Germany effective January 1, 2024, assigning Contract Type as Permanent.         
  2. After replication, enter the following values directly into Infotype 0016 in the Payroll system (PA30 or Infotype UI mashups):
    • Sick Pay Supplement Period Number: 3
    • Sick Pay Supplement Period Unit: months                                                                                                     
  3. Update the employeeâ€™s contract type to Part-time in EC by creating a new record in Job Information, effective from June 1, 2024.                                                                                                              
  4. After the next replication:
    • A new time slice is created in Infotype 0016, effective from June 1, 2024, with the Contract Type updated to Part-time.                                      
    • The existing values of KGZFR and KGZFH fields are retained in the existing time-slice and carry forwarded to the new time-slice effective from June 1, 2024.

The following visual illustrates how BIB replication works now with Field Level Infotype Update :-

Key Benefits

  • Maximize Cloud Capabilities: Extend your cloud footprint by leveraging the full potential of Employee Central as the core HR system of record.
  • Reduce Operational Costs  : Avoid embedding complex business logic or unnecessary custom fields in Employee Central for data that belongs to Payroll domain and not relevant for running core HR business processes.
  • Establish Role-Based Data Governance : Establish clear boundaries between HR and Payroll teams, allowing each to manage data relevant to their domain, improving governance and operational efficiency.
  • Seamless Data Continuity During Payroll System Upgrade : A consistent data cut between Core HR and Payroll ensures a smooth and reliable transition from SAP ERP HCM to SAP S/4 HANA on-premise or SAP S/4 HANA Private Cloud Edition.

Conclusion: 

We truly value your feedback on this new functionality and would love to hear your thoughts on which additional Infotypes you would like to see supported, beyond Infotype 0001 (Organizational Assignment) and Infotype 0016 (Contract Elements).

Please feel free to share your suggestions, requirements, or expectations in the comments section. Your input plays a key role in shaping future enhancements, and we look forward to collaborating with you to improve our solution.

entry.title: HI Community Members,In SAP Ariba B&I, is there any way to make a dropdown Seelction field availab
entry.content:
Hi, Community Members,

In SAP Ariba B&I, is there any way to make Master Data-"Commodity Code with HSN" available at Supplier Ariba Portal as dropdown Selection field to Select while creating a Non- PO Invoice.?

entry.title: Re: HI Community Members,In SAP Ariba B&I, is there any w...
entry.content:
Yes, in SAP Ariba Buying and Invoicing (B&I), it is generally possible to configure the system to allow the Commodity Code to be selected by a Supplier on the SAP Business Network (Ariba Portal) when creating a Non-PO Invoice.

Here are the key points regarding this functionality and the inclusion of HSN (Harmonized System of Nomenclature) details:

Commodity Code Availability: For non-PO invoices created by suppliers on the Ariba Network, there is typically a field for Commodity Code at the line-item level. This field can be presented as a dropdown or a search field. This is a standard feature to categorize the goods or services being invoiced, and it's essential for subsequent tax calculations and spend analysis within Ariba B&I.

Master Data Configuration: The commodity codes (including your HSN-based codes) must be configured and imported into SAP Ariba as System Commodity Codes or ERP Commodity Codes.

HSN Codes in the Indian context are a type of classification code often mapped to the standard Ariba/UNSPSC commodity code structure, or they may be loaded as your ERP Commodity Codes.

The relevant master data files (like SystemCommodityCodes.csv and mapping files like ERPCommoditytoCommodityMap.csv) need to be correctly loaded into your Ariba realm.

Supplier Experience: When the supplier creates the non-PO invoice, they will be prompted to select a Commodity Code for each line item. The values available in the dropdown/search will be based on the commodity code master data that has been configured and synchronized to the Ariba Network.

Enabling HSN/Tax-Specific Fields: If you need the full HSN number (often more detailed than the core commodity code) to be visible or selectable, you might need to use specific tax configuration or custom fields if the standard commodity code field isn't sufficient for your HSN requirement. Commodity codes are commonly associated with tax codes in files like TaxCodeLookup.csv to drive tax calculations, which is how the HSN relationship is often managed in Ariba.

In summary, the functionality to present a Commodity Code dropdown selection to the supplier for non-PO invoices is standard in SAP Ariba B&I, and your HSN-related codes would be part of this master data configuration.

entry.title: Custom codelist in SAP Sales , Service and Enterprise Service Management
entry.content:
In the fast-moving world of business today, managing customer relationships effectively is essential for growth and achieving success. Companies often have to manage vast amounts of customer data, interactions, and updates, which need to be organized, monitored, and examined to make better decisions. Although many CRM systems offer standard lists for fields like "Lead Source" or "Contact Status," each business has its own unique needs, and custom code lists can address those.

A custom code list is a tailored set of codes and their descriptions, created to fit the specific needs of your organization. Instead of relying only on pre-set options, you can define your own set of values for dropdowns, statuses, types, and more within your CRM. These lists help standardize data entry, streamline reporting, and support the unique workflow or terminology used in your business.

Link for SAP Help Portal for step-by-step details for configuration -https://help.sap.com/docs/CX_NG_SVC/56436b4e8fa84dc8b4408c7795a012c4/71cfc3f7baf54f85b5c2e091af9972e2.html

Features:

  • Create custom codelist till 2000 values.
  • Created custom codelist can be used to create extension fields in different entities.
  •  Administrator will be able to set the sorting configuration for custom codelist based on code and description.
  • We can use custom codelist for generating analytical reports.

Demo videos:

https://video.sap.com/media/t/1_roxww0kq

entry.title: Re: VAT report Germany
entry.content:
No, the S_ALR_87012357 report without checking â€œElectronic Advance Returnâ€ is not sufficient for Elster submission. 2. The error message F0T_B2A414 indicates a configuration issue with the reporting period that must end on the last day of the month for Elster compatibility.

Without checking the box, the report generates transaction types and tax codes, which are useful for internal review and reconciliation. However, Elster submission requires tax box mapping and XML output that aligns with the official schema used by the German tax authorities. Therefore, you must use the â€œElectronic Advance Returnâ€ option to generate the correct format for Elster. This includes Tax box assignments / XML structure / Validated period and totals. So the conclusion is the unchecked version is useful for review but not sufficient for official submission.

This error typically means that the reporting period you selected does not end on the last calendar day of the month, which is a requirement for Elster. The common causes would be

  • You selected a custom date range (e.g., 01.10.2025 to 30.10.2025 instead of 31.10.2025).
  • The fiscal period configuration in your system does not align with calendar months.
  • The VAT reporting period setup in table T007A or T007S is misaligned.

To fix this, ensure the reporting period ends on the last day of the month. For October, use 01.10.2025 to 31.10.2025.

Make sure each tax code is assigned to the correct tax box in transaction OBYZ.

Use transaction OBY6 to check company code settings. Use SM30 to view and adjust entries in T007A and T007S.

entry.title: Re: Rework Order not created while rejecting inspection lot
entry.content:
Message L3007: â€œData for storage type search is not defined (A FLR Q)â€ is triggered when SAP cannot determine the correct storage type during transfer order creation. A FLR Q refers to:

  • A: Movement type indicator (e.g., putaway)
  • FLR: Storage location
  • Q: Stock category (e.g., Quality Inspection)

This error typically occurs when storage type search configuration is missing for the combination of movement type, storage location, and stock category.

Go to SPRO â†’ Logistics Execution â†’ Warehouse Management â†’ Activities â†’ Transfers â†’ Define Storage Type Search. Ensure that storage type search entries exist for Movement type (e.g., 321 or 343 for inspection lot rejection), Storage location (e.g., FLR) & Stock category (e.g., Q).

Go to OMLY or SPRO â†’ Enterprise Structure â†’ Assignment â†’ Logistics Execution â†’ Assign Warehouse Number to Plant/Storage Location. Make sure the plant and storage location are correctly assigned to a warehouse number.

Use transaction LT06 to manually simulate the transfer order creation. If it fails, check the storage type search sequence and control indicators.

Since the issue is plant-specific, compare the WM configuration of the working plant with the problematic plant. Look for missing entries in Storage type search, Movement type configuration and Storage location setup

entry.title: SAP S4 HANA Finance integration and Use case with SAP Joule
entry.content:
What Is SAP Joule?

SAP Joule is SAPâ€™s AI copilot embedded across its cloud applications. It offers four interaction typesâ€”Transactional, Navigational, Informational, and Analyticalâ€”that let users perform business tasks via natural language within SAP environments. It understands user context, roles, permissions, and remains secure by design. It can also ground responses in your own business documents.

 How SAP Joule works in Public vs. Private Cloud is one of the most important considerations for finance teams (especially in FICO) deciding on adoption.

Hereâ€™s a structured view:

 SAP Joule in Public vs. Private Cloud

Deployment & Integration

  • Public Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)
    • Joule is natively embedded and updated by SAP automatically.
    • Integration with SAP FICO apps (GL, AP, AR, Asset Accounting, Controlling) is out of the box.
    • No additional installation required - users just activate and configure.
  • Private Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition)
    • Joule can be enabled, but may require additional setup and integration.
    • Some Joule features might lag behind public cloud, because public gets innovations first.
    • Still integrates with FICO, but might require extra configuration & tenant connections to SAP BTP.

Feature Availability

  • Public Cloud
    • Joule supports all 4 interaction types (Transactional, Navigational, Informational, Analytical) directly in Fiori apps.
    • Example in FICO: â€œPost vendor invoiceâ€ â†’ transaction executes directly.
    • Faster delivery of Joule Agents and Joule Studio.
  • Private Cloud
    • Informational & Analytical features available early (queries, reports, insights).
    • Transactional flows may require enablement through custom skills/agents.
    • Joule Studio can still be connected via SAP BTP, but adoption speed depends on customerâ€™s upgrade cycle.

Customization & Extensibility

  • Public Cloud
    • Limited custom codingâ€”extensions must go through SAP BTP side-by-side development.
    • Joule skills/agents are mostly standardized.
    • Great if you want speed & standardization.
  • Private Cloud
    • More flexibility: you can create custom FICO processes, reports, and Joule agents.
    • Easier to integrate with on-prem or legacy systems.
    • Suited for companies with complex finance processes.

Data Security & Residency

  • Public Cloud
    • Data is hosted on SAP-managed hyperscalers (AWS, Azure, GCP, SAP DCs).
    • Joule queries financial data via secure APIs; customers rely on SAPâ€™s compliance.
  • Private Cloud
    • You control hosting, location, and more of the security stack.
    • Some finance-heavy industries (banking, defense, public sector) may prefer this for regulatory reasons.

Upgrade & Innovation

  • Public Cloud
    • Quarterly upgrades â†’ Joule features arrive first and fastest.
    • Example: New Joule Agents for FICO tasks (like dispute resolution) appear immediately.
  • Private Cloud
    • Annual upgrades (with optional Feature Packs).
    • Joule features arrive laterâ€”innovation follows public cloud by a few cycles.

 Comparison Table

Aspect

Public Cloud

Private Cloud

Availability

Native, out-of-the-box

Needs setup, later adoption

Updates

Quarterly, fastest innovations

Annual/controlled upgrades

Customization

Limited, BTP-based

Flexible, deep customizations

Security

SAP-managed hyperscalers

Customer-controlled

FICO Use Cases

Immediate transactional & analytical support

Strong for complex, regulated finance scenarios

Joule Studio

Fully available

Available via BTP, more flexible

 Which is Better for FICO?

  • Public Cloud â†’ Best if you want rapid innovation, standard finance processes, faster AI adoption.
  • Private Cloud â†’ Best if you need deep customization, strict compliance, hybrid IT integration.

 SAP Joule version requirements for S/4HANA Cloud editions (Public and Private):

  1. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Joule arrived as part of the Public Cloud starting around Q3 2024, and is embedded in all releases thereafter, including 2408 (August 2024) and onward.
  • While Joule is built into these releases, you still need proper entitlement and authorization to use it; this may require activation via your SAP admin or account executive.
  • There are setup guides available detailing how to activate Joule once entitlement is granted.

In Summary:

If your system is on Public Cloud release 2408 (Aug 2024) or later, Joule is already supportedâ€”assuming you've got the right access and permissions.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition

  • Joule is available in the Private Cloud as well, but requires setup and configuration. It's not automatically activeâ€”you must enable it via SAP BTP and Joule Studio.
  • Technical prerequisites include ensuring the UI5 version in your system meets or exceeds the minimum required for Joule integration. The specific UI5 version will depend on your release; you can consult SAP documentation for exact details.

In Summary:

Private Cloud systems can support Jouleâ€”but you must set it up, ensure the UI5 stack is compatible, and configure the feature via BTP.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise (Classic)

  • Joule is not supported on on-premise S/4HANA. SAP has confirmed it's not on the current roadmap for classic on-premise systems.
  • Thereâ€™s a planned strategyâ€”possibly coming Q1 2025â€”to enable Joule via SAP Build Work Zone, BTP, and Joule Studio even for on-prem systems. But as of now, Joule remains unavailable on-prem and unsupported.

High-Level Overview

Edition

Supported from (release)

Requirements

Public Cloud

2408 (Aug 2024) onward

Needs entitlement/authorization & activation

Private Cloud

Post-2024 releases

Requires UI5 prerequisites + BTP/Joule Studio setup

On-Premise (classic)

Not supported (as of now)

No Joule availability; roadmap may include future BTP-based solution

Summary:

  • Public Cloud: Joule is supported starting with 2408 onwardâ€”activate it via entitlement.
  • Private Cloud: Joule is available but not automaticâ€”requires UI compliance + setup via BTP.
  • On-Premise: Joule is not supported yet; no built-in version availability.

Hereâ€™s how SAP Joule, SAPâ€™s generative AI assistant, can be applied specifically within the SAP FICO (Finance & Controlling) domain:

SAP Joule Application in FICO

  • Transactional Interactions

Joule allows users to perform CRUD operations and manage financial documents via natural languageâ€”imagine asking:

  • â€œPost a vendor invoice of $5,000 to account X with due date Y.â€
  • â€œShow me the status of PO invoice 10234.â€
    While SAP hasn't yet released out-of-the-box FICO conversational flows, Jouleâ€™s transactional model supports this kind of interaction across cloud applications.
  • Navigational Interactions

Instead of navigating through menus to reach Fiori apps like â€œDisplay GL Account Balances,â€ you could simply ask:

  • â€œWhere can I review G/L balances?â€
    Joule will direct you to the relevant screen.
  • Informational Interactions

Straight answers instead of digging through help docs. You can ask:

  • â€œWhatâ€™s the difference between cost center and profit center accounting?â€
  • â€œExplain account determination for automatic postings.â€
    Joule will deliver concise explanations, referencing SAP documentation or your own policy documents.

Analytical Interactions

Joule bridges your natural-language queries to data analytics:

  • â€œShow me quarterly expense trends per cost center.â€
  • â€œWhich cost centers exceeded budget last quarter?â€
    It returns charts, metrics, or dashboardsâ€”leveraging SAP Analytics Cloud integration.

Advanced: Joule Agents & Studio

Joule Agents

SAP has introduced AI agentsâ€”autonomous actors capable of executing complex, multi-step workflows across business functions. In FICO, custom agents could:

  • Automate dispute resolution: Collaborate across finance and service teams to validate discrepancies and propose corrections.
  • Cash collection workflows: Analyze overdue invoices, coordinate with collections, and initiate follow-ups.
    These agents are part of SAPâ€™s cross-functional automation strategy.

Joule Studio (within SAP Build)

No-code/low-code tool to create custom skills or agents tailored for your FICO needs:

  • Build a skill to automatically generate internal financial reports, or trigger approval workflows.
  • Automate vendor reconciliation or recurring postings by designing tailored AI agents.
    These skills and agents integrate across SAP and non-SAP systems.

Summary Table

Joule Capability

FICO Use Case Example

Transactional

Post invoices, check payment status via natural language

Navigational

Ask â€œWhere to view Cost Center Reports?â€

Informational

Clarify financial terms or posting rules

Analytical

Generate trends and KPI charts using SAC

Agents & Studio

Automate dispute resolution, cash collection, approvals

Key Benefits in FICO

  • Boost Productivity: Save time by speaking instead of clicking through screens.
  • Reduce Errors: Leverage conversational clarity and auto-generated documents.
  • Improve Insights: Conduct data reviews and root cause analysis through simple dialogue.
  • Automate Complex Workflows: Agents handle multi-step tasks such as reconciliations or approvals automatically.

Real-World Usage Context -- Caveats

While SAP is rapidly developing Jouleâ€™s capabilities, many implementations remain in pilot or PoC stages. Users in forums report limited early usage, primarily for basic navigation or queries.

Here are concrete FICO scenarios where you could pilot SAP Joule and even extend it with Joule Agents / Studio:

 Pilot Scenarios in SAP FICO

  1. Invoice & Payment Handling
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œPost an invoice for vendor ABC with $12,000 due in 30 days.â€
  • Joule Action: Creates the posting, validates tax code, and confirms with you.
  • Extension with Agent: Automate follow-upâ€”if payment not cleared by due date, Joule Agent triggers a reminder email or escalates.
  1. Month-End Close Assistant
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œWhat are the pending tasks for month-end close?â€
  • Joule Action: Lists open items (accruals, GR/IR clearing, reconciliations).
  • Extension with Agent: Automate recurring accrual postings and send alerts to approvers who are late in providing confirmations.
  1. Financial Analysis & Insights
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œShow me expense trend per cost center for last 6 months.â€
  • Joule Action: Returns a chart (via SAC integration).
  • Extension with Agent: Forecast next quarterâ€™s expenses and flag cost centers that may exceed budgets.
  1. Audit & Compliance Checks
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œList journal entries above $50,000 in the last quarter without approvals.â€
  • Joule Action: Generates a filtered list.
  • Extension with Agent: Create an automated internal audit agent that periodically checks for compliance exceptions and notifies controllers.
  1. Treasury & Cash Management
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œWhat is todayâ€™s cash position?â€
  • Joule Action: Summarizes bank balances, incoming/outgoing payments.
  • Extension with Agent: Auto-generate a daily treasury dashboard at 9 AM and send to CFO.
  1. Dispute & Collections Management
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œShow me customers with invoices overdue > 60 days.â€
  • Joule Action: Lists overdue accounts.
  • Extension with Agent: An AI agent sends personalized payment reminders and schedules calls with collections staff.
  1. Budget vs. Actual Control
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œWhich cost centers exceeded budget last quarter?â€
  • Joule Action: Shows variances with drill-down.
  • Extension with Agent: Automatically notify budget owners when variances exceed a threshold (say 10%).

 How to Design in Joule Studio

In Joule Studio (within SAP Build) you can:

  1. Create a Skill â†’ â€œGenerate quarterly P&L by company code and send PDF to finance team.â€
  2. Create an Agent â†’ â€œMonitor overdue vendor payments and auto-initiate dunning.â€
  3. Connect Non-SAP Apps â†’ e.g., send approvals via MS Teams or Slack.

 

 This way, Joule moves from a copilot (answering queries) to a colleague (executing finance tasks for you).

 

Deep Dive on one of the real-world example: Vendor Invoice Posting with SAP Joule in Public vs Private Cloud.

 Example: Vendor Invoice Posting with Joule

 Scenario

A finance user wants to post a vendor invoice for Vendor 300012, amount $12,000, due in 30 days.

 Public Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)

  • User says to Joule:
    â€œPost a vendor invoice of $12,000 for Vendor 300012, due in 30 days.
  • Joule Process:
    1. Understands the intent (â€œCreate Vendor Invoiceâ€).
    2. Pulls relevant master data (Vendor 300012 details, tax code, payment terms).
    3. Pre-fills the invoice screen in Fiori.
    4. User confirms â†’ Invoice is posted.
  • Extras in Public Cloud:
    • Joule can immediately display the document number and due date schedule.
    • If connected to SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), Joule can also show how this impacts cash outflow forecast.
    • Minimal setup â†’ available out-of-the-box.

 Private Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition)

  • User says to Joule:
     â€œPost a vendor invoice of $12,000 for Vendor 300012, due in 30 days.â€
  • Joule Process:
    • Provide navigation â†’ â€œOpen FB60 (Vendor Invoice Entry)â€ or â€œFiori App: Create Supplier Invoice.â€
    • Pre-fill metadata only if integrated with custom Joule Skill via Joule Studio.
    1. Joule recognizes intent, but instead of direct posting, it may:
    2. User manually confirms or adjusts in the classic posting screen (e.g., FB60 / MIRO).
    3. Invoice is posted.
  • Extras in Private Cloud:
    • You can customize Joule Agent (via Joule Studio + BTP) to enforce company-specific validations (e.g., block invoices >$10,000 without 2 approvals).
    • Joule can connect to legacy non-SAP apps (like OCR invoice scanners or in-house workflow systems).
    • Requires more setup & governance compared to Public Cloud.

 Side-by-Side Comparison

Step

Public Cloud

Private Cloud

Activation

Native, plug-and-play

Needs setup & integration

Invoice Posting

Joule executes directly in Fiori app

Joule suggests navigation, may require custom agent for automation

Data Validation

Standard rules auto-applied

Flexible, can embed custom compliance rules

User Effort

Minimal (voice/text â†’ posted)

Moderate (confirmation in screen, extra steps if no custom agent)

Analytics

Immediate cash flow impact via SAC

Possible, but may need manual SAC integration

Customization

Limited (SAP-standard process)

Flexible (custom workflows, approvals, legacy integration)

Key Takeaway:

  • In Public Cloud, Joule = speed + simplicity â†’ perfect for companies with standard finance processes.
  • In Private Cloud, Joule = control + flexibility â†’ better if you need extra compliance steps, custom posting logic, or hybrid integration.

entry.title: Index-Based Asset Revaluation in Argentina with SAP S/4HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Understanding Index-Based Asset Revaluation

In Argentina, companies must periodically revalue their fixed assets to reflect inflationary changes. SAP's new feature automates this process, ensuring compliance with local regulations. By using the Maintain Asset Revaluation Index app, businesses can create and manage revaluation indices, which are then applied to asset master records for accurate valuation. When Depreciation Posting runs, the depreciation area will also post the revaluation by the Index registered (if it was assigned in the Fixed Asset Master Data)â€ in the Manage Monthly Closing Activities section.

Prerequisites

To be able to post a revaluation in a specific depreciation area, revaluation must be allowed in the depreciation area. SAP has defined for each depreciation area in the predefined configuration whether revaluation is allowed.

Step 1: Maintain Asset Revaluation Index

1. Open the Maintain Asset Revaluation Index app.

2. Choose Create and specify the following details:

   - Revaluation Index ID: Freely selectable (independent of a specific company code)

   - Index Type: Replacement Value, Monthly

4. Choose Continue.

5. On the Asset Revaluation Index page, in the Header section, specify values for all mandatory (*) fields, such as Index Description, Country/Region Key, and Currency

6. In the Index Items section, specify the index values such as the Valid To dates. The system automatically sets the Valid From dates.

7. Choose Create.

 At this point, the indexâ€™s lifecycle status is Created.

8. Choose Activate to make the index available for valuation views.

The indexâ€™s lifecycle status changes to Active.
For more information: see Maintain Asset Revaluation Index | SAP Help Portal

Step 2: Create Asset Master Record

You can use the Manage Fixed Assets app (F3425) to create and view asset master records and display asset values for each valuation.

You can create a new fixed asset from scratch, or you can use an existing fixed asset as a template. For more information on Manage Fixed Assets app (F3425), please refer to Manage Fixed Assets | SAP Help Portal

For more information on how to create asset master data, please refer to Creating Fixed Asset Master Data | SAP Help Portal

 Post Asset Acquisition

1. Open the Post Asset Acquisition app.

2. Choose Post > Post Acquisition > Acquisition (Net).

3. Specify all the mandatory values.

4. Choose Simulate to simulate the accounting posting.

5. Choose the expand icon to display all ledgers.
For more details on the Post Asset Acquisition app, see
Post Asset Acquisition - And Quantity Adjustment | SAP Help Portal

View Journal Entries

1. In the Post Asset Acquisition app, go to the Journal Entries tab, choose the document number of the journal entry, and then choose Display Journal Entries â€“ New Version.

The system navigates to the Display Journal Entries app.

2. Go to the Line Items tab and choose T-Account View.

The accounting postings are displayed in the Display Journal Entries â€“ In T-Account View app.

For more details, see Display Journal Entries â€“ In T-Account View | SAP Help Portal

View Revaluations for the Fixed Asset

1. Open the Manage Fixed Assets app.

2. Search for and open the fixed asset that you created in Step 2.

3. On the Valuation tab, click the small right arrow to choose the depreciation area for which you want to view the revaluations.

4. Display the values by fiscal year or currency, as required.

This section acts as the "Fixed Asset Explorer", where the values are displayed at different times of the fiscal year.

5. Choose Explain Key Figures for information on the displayed values.

6. Go to the Journal Entries tab to view all documents posted in this depreciation area for this asset. These values can be displayed by fiscal year and currency.

7. Go to the Depreciation tab to view ordinary and revaluated depreciations for different fiscal periods.

Manage Monthly Closing Activities

1. Open the Schedule Asset Accounting Jobs app.

2. Choose Create.

3. Choose the job template Depreciation Posting Run and choose Step 2.

4. Set a schedule for the job to run and choose Step 3.5. To schedule and run the job, choose Schedule.

6. Choose the job and download the results.

View the depreciation values in the Manage Fixed Assets app.

For more details, see Schedule Asset Accounting Jobs | SAP Help Portal

Reporting: Reporting | SAP Help Portal

1. Use the Asset Accounting Overview app to access key information and KPIs within the Asset Accounting area, and gain insight into current trends.

2. Use the Asset Balances app to display balances of fixed assets according to various criteria, such as company code, depreciation area, segment, or profit center.

3. Use the Asset Transactions app to check and evaluate daily or monthly operations in Asset Accounting by listing asset transactions posted to the general ledger.

4. Use the Depreciation Lists app as a supplement to the profit and loss statement.

5. Use the Asset History Sheet app to display the asset history sheet, which shows value changes to the fixed asset balances in a fiscal year for a depreciation area.

Summary

The explained process of revaluation by indexes allows to cover the basic cases of the inflation adjustment process for fixed assets in Argentina means a simpler way. Additionally, the complex and non-common cases could be supported by extensibility.

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Monitor Material Coverage - Net and Individual Segments Manage Material Coverage & Production Planning

To summarise, in public cloud edition, the monitor material coverage-net and individual segments app already provides standard navigation to the monitor material coverage app. This has replaced the former MD04 transaction. When you click the Material Number in the Net and Individual Segments list, the system automatically launches the Single Material view with the selected material, plant and MRP area will be prefilled.

Below is a description on how to navigate.

  • Open the Monitor Material Coverage,
  • Select Net and individual Segments,
  • Select an MRP standard definition and locate the Material number with a shortage.

  • Click the hyperlink of your choice as shown below. The system opens the Monitor Material Coverage app.
  • Verify that the material number, plant, and MRP are fields are automatically prefilled.
  • Thereafter you see the stock/replenishment list equivalent (formerly MD04).

 

If this navigation does not work on your system, please verify that both apps are included in your business role SAP_BR_PRODN_PLNR_MRP and that you have the correct catalog assignments.

You do not require any additional configuration or enhancement because this is standard behaviour for the public cloud.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Migrating NowShortUrl of QR-codes from old company to...
entry.content:
Data API provides full read/write access to most of the data in a company, including NowShortUrlDTO. It is theoretically feasible with Data API to GET all NowShortUrlDTO objects from the old company A, and PUT them into the new company B.

However, there are two major caveats:

  • If the object reference of a NowShortUrlDTO is set to an object that belongs to company A, it will be invalid in company B, unless company B has been restored from a full data backup of company A.
  • The actual URLs of the the NowShortUrlDTO are permanently linked to the company they are originally created in. In practice, scanning such a QR-code will always direct the user to the Self-Service Portal of company A. This hard link cannot be changed via Data API (or any other available API).

entry.title: Enterprise Messaging in SAP: JMS vs Event Mesh vs AMQP Adapter
entry.content:
All three that is JMS, Event Mesh and AMQP adapters are widely used in SAP for different purposes. The common thing among all these three is that these three are asynchronous adapters.

Asynchronous means they send message without waiting for the response or they work independently. That means there is no need for both the sender and receiver to interact and work together.

Understanding the Basics 

Now let's just see the basics of each adapter and then dive deeper to the main part of the blog.

JMS 

JMS adapter stands for Java Message Service. It is used in cases where we need guaranteed message delivery by storing in queue (if needed) with CPI system. It is not specifically built for cloud-native or event driven architecture.

SAP Event Mesh

This is used in both cloud systems and event driven. It can be said cloud native as it is designed to run in cloud environments. Event driven as it is built around Pub-Sub (Publish-Subscribe) model. This is used widely for connecting outside the CPI system. This has many adapters like AMQP, MQTT(Message Queuing Protocol) and HTTP REST.

AMQP Adapter

AMQP stands for Advanced Event Mesh. It acts as a bridge between application and broker. Broker is nothing but an event broker like Solace. It is primarily an event driven architecture but can also be a part of cloud native architecture depending on the usage.

When to Use What?

Hereâ€™s how I usually decide between these options:

  • Go with JMS if...
    Youâ€™re working with java centric enterprise environment, need reliable messaging and on premise that in within the CI/CPI system.

  • Choose Event Mesh if...
    Youâ€™re working on cloud native or IOT applications, need real time event routing and need dynamic event distribution.

  • Use the AMQP Adapter if...
    You need to connect event brokers like any third-party broker system, interoperable messaging and control over message delivery, routing and reliability.

Real-World Scenarios

Let me share a couple of examples to put this into context:

  1. Legacy ECC System + JMS:
    In one project, wherein we needed a guaranteed message delivery, I used 2 I-flows and it was within the CPI system that is on premise system. For this JMS was the best adapter. We have to give the queue name, and select whether it's exclusive or non-exclusive.

  2. AMQP Adapter with Third-Party Systems:
    In another case, I needed to integrate SAP with a third-party logistics provider using Solace. So in this case this was the best suited as it is cloud supported. We have to give the username and password of solace adapter, give the credential name that we create in security material section.

So, the thing between choosing JMS, AMQP or Event Mesh depends on the situation and what is needed for a particular situation. So, with so many options being available on SAP, we have to make a wise choice to choose between the available adapters.

JMS vs Event Mesh vs AMQP Adapter

 

FeatureJMSEvent MeshAMQP Adapter
Best ForLegacy SAP (PI/PO, ECC)Cloud-native SAP (BTP, S/4)Hybrid SAP + external systems
ArchitectureTightly coupledLoosely coupled, event-drivenProtocol-based integration
ScalabilityLimitedHighDepends on external broker
Integration EffortLow (in legacy)Low (in BTP)Moderate
Real-Time SupportLimitedExcellentGood


Features JMS Event Mesh AMQP Adapter
*Best For Legacy SAP (PI/PO, ECC) Cloud-native SAP (BTP, S/4) Hybrid SAP + external systems.
*Architecture Tightly coupled Loosely coupled, event-driven Protocol-based integration.
*Scalability Limited High Depends on external broker.
*Integration Effort Low (in legacy) Low (in BTP) Moderate.
*Real-Time Support Limited Excellent Good.

Conclusion:

Picking the Right Messaging Tool for Your SAP Landscape
At the end of the day, choosing between JMS, Event Mesh, and the AMQP Adapter isnâ€™t about which one is â€œbetterâ€â€”itâ€™s about which one fits your current architecture, integration goals, and future roadmap.

If you're working with legacy SAP systems like PI/PO or ECC, JMS is still a solid choice. Itâ€™s stable, well-supported, and gets the job done in tightly coupled environments.

But if you're moving toward SAP BTP or building event-driven, cloud-native applications, Event Mesh is the way forward. Itâ€™s built for scale, flexibility, and real-time responsivenessâ€”exactly what modern enterprise landscapes need.

And when youâ€™re dealing with external systemsâ€”whether itâ€™s a logistics partner using RabbitMQ or a cloud service on Azureâ€”AMQP Adapter gives you the protocol-level integration you need without compromising on standards or reliability.

So, my advice? Start with your architecture and business needs, then choose the messaging tool that aligns best. And rememberâ€”these tools arenâ€™t mutually exclusive. In many real-world SAP landscapes, youâ€™ll find all three working together to keep data flowing smoothly across systems.

So, it's not just creating an I-flow and using whichever we feel better. It's about choosing the best among the available options and that which is practical for the application for which we are using a particular adapter. We have to choose the one with better efficiency. SAP has provided us with so many options, we have to choose the best one and it's important.

entry.title: Strengthening Security on SAP BTP Neo Environment with DigiCert Global Root G3
entry.content:
At SAP, keeping your data and applications secure is always a top priority.
To further strengthen the security of the SAP BTP Neo environment, we are migrating to the â€œDigiCert Global Root G3â€ Public Key Infrastructure (PKI). This update ensures long-term trust, improved encryption, and compliance with the latest international security standards.

Do You Need to Do Anything

For most customers, no action is required.
Modern web browsers (like Google Chrome and Mozilla Firefox) and up-to-date operating systems already trust the new DigiCert Global Root G3 certificate automatically.

However, if your organization manages certificates manually or maintains its own trust store, your technical team should add the new G3 certificate before the March 2026 deadline.
This ensures continued, secure access to SAP BTP services.

Important: Do not remove the existing G2 certificate â€” both should remain active during the transition.

Why This Matters

This change is part of SAPâ€™s ongoing commitment to:

  • Keep your data and applications secure
  • Align with the latest global and national security standards
  • Ensure continued compatibility with modern browsers and systems

By making this upgrade, SAP is helping customers stay protected and ready for the future.

Timeline

The full migration to DigiCert Global Root G3 will take effect in March 2026.

Until then, both the G2 and G3 certificates will remain active to ensure a smooth transition.

How to Add the DigiCert Global Root G3 Certificate

If you manage your own trust stores, please follow these steps:

  1. Visit the DigiCert root certificate page: https://www.digicert.com/kb/digicert-root-certificates.htm
  2. Locate â€œDigiCert Global Root G3.â€
  3. Download the appropriate certificate format for your environment.
  4. Verify the certificate fingerprint using your preferred tool (for example, with OpenSSL:
    openssl x509 -noout -text -in ./DigiCertGlobalRootG3.crt.pem -fingerprint)
  5. Follow your trust storeâ€™s instructions to add the certificate.

For guidance on managing trusted certificates for SAP BTP, see the BTP Trust Store on GitHub. To streamline future updates, we recommend applying the BTP Trust Store regularly or automating this process.

Affected Domains

This update applies to the following platform domains in the SAP BTP Neo environment:

*.<Region.Domain> 

*.dispatcher.<Region.Domain> 

*.cert.<Region.Domain> 

*.static.<Region.Domain> 

*.vms.<Region.Domain> 

*.netweaver.ondemand.com 

connectivitynotification.<Region.Domain> 

connectivitytunnel.<Region.Domain>

For a full overview of regions and domain hosts, see the SAP Help Portal.

Custom Domains

SAP-owned custom domains are not affected by this change until March 2026.
After this date, all new automated certificate renewals will use the DigiCert Global Root G3 certificate. New SAP-owned custom domains created after March 2026 will also use G3 by default.


Staying secure is a shared effort â€” and weâ€™re making it easier for you.
With the DigiCert Global Root G3 upgrade, SAP BTP continues to offer a trusted, reliable, and compliant cloud environment for your business.

entry.title: How to Call an SAP BTP Kyma Function from AWS Lambda â€” Step by Step
entry.content:
Ever tried to make AWS Lambda talk to a Kyma Function on SAP BTP and ended up buried in docs and 400 errors? Same. In this post, Iâ€™ll walk you through the simplest setup that actually works â€” a Lambda sending JSON to Kyma over HTTPS, step by step.

(From the code snippets, substitute, 'KYMA_CLUSTER_DOMAIN' for your Kyma Cluster Domain).

To recreate this setup, you only need a few free-tier tools and basic access:

Accounts & Platforms

  • AWS Free Tier account â€“ with permissions to create and run a Lambda function.
  • SAP BTP Free Tier account â€“ with access to the Kyma runtime (trial or free tier).
  • GitHub (optional) â€“ if you want to version your function or YAML files.

Local Tools

  • Shell or Terminal â€“ any terminal works (Mac Terminal, Windows PowerShell, WSL, etc.).
  • kubectl â€“ the Kubernetes CLI, configured to connect to your Kyma cluster.
  • Visual Studio Code (VSC) â€“ for editing the function code and YAML files (not strictly necessary, but a nice to have!)
  • curl â€“ to test your public Kyma endpoint from the command line.

First, we will create a function called, 'message-function'. You'll find Functions are under Namespaces->your_namespace->Functions

Click on, 'Create', name it, 'message-function', set the Language to' JavaScript' and the Runtime to, 'Nodejs 22'and leave the rest as default. 

In the, 'Source' tab, add the below code: 

module.exports = {
  main: async function (event, context) {
    let input;
    try {
      if (!event.data) {
        input = {};
      } else if (typeof event.data === "string") {
        input = JSON.parse(event.data);
      } else {
        input = event.data;
      }
    } catch (err) {
      console.error("Parse error:", err.message);
      return {
        statusCode: 400,
        body: {
          error: "Invalid JSON payload",
          details: err.message
        }
      };
    }

    console.log("Received payload:", input);

    return {
      statusCode: 200,
      body: {
        message: "Hello from Kyma â€” message-function working!",
        received: input
      }
    };
  }
};

Click, 'Create': 

Click, 'save' and wait for the status of the function to turn to a, 'Running' state (here you can see it in an, 'unknown' state: 

It should go to 'Ready' in a couple of seconds or so: 

Create a file named message-function-apirule.yaml with this content:

Then apply it: 

ac:ui5-test neilaspin$ kubectl apply -f message-function-apirule.yaml

You should see: 

apirule.gateway.kyma-project.io/message-function created

Then check ('-n' specifies the namespace that you're using):

kubectl get apirule -n dev

 You should get something like this back: 

message-function     Ready ["message-function.<KYMA_CLUSTER_DOMAIN"]

Test it again: 

$ curl -X POST https://message-function.<KYMA_CLUSTER_DOMAIN>   -H "Content-Type: application/json"   -d '{"test":"direct"}'

You should see something like this: 

Hello world from the Kyma Function message-function running on nodejs22!(base)

Now lets work through the Lambda stuff!
In AWS Console->Lambda->Functions->Create Function

Add the below code into your 'index.mjs' file: 

// index.js (CommonJS)
const https = require("https");

exports.handler = async (event) => {
  const data = JSON.stringify({
    from: "AWS Lambda",
    time: new Date().toISOString(),
    echo: event || {}
  });

  const options = {
    hostname: "message-function.<KYMA_CLUSTER_DOMAIN>",
    port: 443,
    path: "/",
    method: "POST",
    headers: {
      "Content-Type": "application/json",
      "Content-Length": Buffer.byteLength(data)
    }
  };

  return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
    const req = https.request(options, (res) => {
      let body = "";
      res.on("data", (chunk) => (body += chunk));
      res.on("end", () => {
        console.log("Kyma replied:", body);
        resolve({ statusCode: res.statusCode, body });
      });
    });

    req.on("error", (err) => {
      console.error("HTTPS error:", err);
      reject(err);
    });

    req.write(data);
    req.end();
  });
};

Create a Test Event with the Even JSON set to '{ "hello": "world" }': 

Click, 'Test' in the top right corner
Then you should see : 

Click on the, 'logs' link (this should take you to CloudWatch): 

Click on the latest logstream at the bottom of the page and you should see some output like below: 

And we're golden!

2025-10-17T07:24:39.081Z	141aa77f-cbdd-4c28-b74a-d56c18519d3e	INFO	Kyma replied: Hello world from the Kyma Function message-function running on nodejs22!

Conclusion: 

With just a Kyma Function, an APIRule, and a few lines of Node.js in AWS Lambda, weâ€™ve built a working integration between AWS and SAP BTP. The Lambda sends a simple JSON payload over HTTPS, Kyma processes it, and responds in real time. This pattern is lightweight, reliable, and scalable â€” perfect for triggering SAP workloads from AWS events without introducing extra middleware or services.

entry.title: Re: SAP FSM Smartform is read-only
entry.content:
Usually the only reason a smartform is read-only is that the person opening it is not set as responsible person. Have you tried using the "Take it" action on the activity and confirm to also take over smartforms? Maybe that fixes as a workaround and better then deleting and recreating?

Otherwise it needs some troubleshooting why sometimes the responsible person is not set correctly in the business rule. Some questions to check:

1. Did you check via query the ids of the responsible person set?

2. Is this happening always for the same users or different people?

3. Any pattern when it works and when it does not work?

If you cannot find out the root cause and fix might be worth to create a support ticket.

entry.title: Overhead costs in Maintenance Orders, Cloud ERP
entry.content:
Collaborative effort of Saurabh Goyal.

Overhead costs in maintenance refer to the indirect expenses associated with keeping assets, equipment, facilities, or infrastructure operational, but that are not directly tied to a specific maintenance task or job.

Why it matters?

  • Maintenance overheads affect the total cost of ownership of equipment.
  • Businesses need to track and allocate these costs accurately to understand true operational expenses.
  • Understanding overhead costs helps in making decisions on repair vs. replace, outsourcing, or investing in predictive maintenance tools.

This blog outlines the necessary process and configuration required to perform this calculation in the public cloud. It also highlights the associated constraints and provides guidance for customers and partners on how to proceed.

Define Costing Sheet (SSCUI 102922 Define Costing Sheets )

Define the material overhead rates for corresponding plant actual /planned

Planning Costing SheetProduction Costing Sheet

Configuration of the assignment costing sheet to valuation variant (SSCUI 102607 :Define Valuation Variants for Material Cost Estimates)

Assign planning costing sheet to valuation variant 006 and production costing sheet to valuation variant 007

Configure Overhead Costs value category for maintenance Order (SSCUI 103792 Maintain Value Categories)

Configure Value category for Maintenance orders. Create a new value category for Overhead costs

Assign relevant Cost element group to newly created value category (SSCUI 103806:Assign Cost Elements to Value Categories)

Overhead calculation as per costing sheet

As you create maintenance order, add material to operation and save, the planned overhead costs are calculated and same is reflected in the costs tab in Overhead costs value category.

In the backend the costing sheet is filled with the costing sheet which we assigned in the configuration SSCUI 102607 above as maintenance order is assigned with costing sheet.

In the below maintenance order we created, the material value is 120000 EUR and corresponding overhead costs according to the overhead rate 7% in the costing sheet will be 0.07*120000 = 8400 EUR

Planned costs updated under cost category overhead costs

Goods issue on the maintenance order

Goods Issue

Run overhead calculation actual

Material Overhead costs calculated

The same is reflected in actual costs for overhead cost category in the maintenance order

Actual overhead costs reflection on Maintenance Order

As illustrated in the scenario above, configuring the costing sheet within the valuation variant enables the business to calculate overhead costs effectively. However, this approach does come with certain limitations, which are outlined in the section below.

Constraints to the process:

  • Since the field is hidden, the process cannot be altered during runtime.

Available options:

  • Assignment of costing sheet to maintenance order type. Customer / partner can vote to the CIP request https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/333625
  • For additional features, new request can be raised.

Thanks for your time and please share your valuable feedback and inputs in a comment below. Also kindly follow the tag SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Asset Management to watch similar content.

You can also post your questions at All Questions in SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Asset Management | SAP Community

entry.title: Re: Introducing CSA Validation in SAP Cloud ALM: Whatâ€™s Live, Whatâ€™s Next, and How You Can Shape it
entry.content:
Dear Shubhra,

thank you very much for your encouraging feedback! Let me respomd as follows:

1. With all disclaimers applicable to forward-looking statements: Ability to create own checks and baseline policies is planned for 2026-Q2. This is planned to come along with a security analysis per check. Until then you can only enable/disable the pre-delivered checks.

2. We'll have some more cloud services for initial release in upcoming weeks.
The program management for the onboarding of BTP and cloud services and the prioritization of related efforts, are not in our hands. Unfortunately, progress is far behind our expectations from SAP Cloud ALM side, too. I'd recommend to create customer influence requests for specific services that are most urgently needed, so that we can follow-up more specifically and address the need for a more effective program. This relates also to more extended configuration data beyond the initial scope of a SAP Security Recommendation status.

Kind regards,
Hendrik Mueller
Product Manager, SAP Cloud ALM Configuration & Security Analysis
